race.name: Traka 360
race.tagline: Europe's Unbound. 360km through Catalonia from dawn to dusk to dawn. Where WorldTour pros meet gravel specialists.

vitals.aid_stations: Multiple feed zones with staffed stops plus town resupply

climate.description: 18-28¬∞C (65-82¬∞F), variable spring weather with morning cold, afternoon heat, possible mountain rain

terrain.primary: Rocky Mediterranean gravel with forest singletrack
terrain.surface: Rocky Mediterranean gravel, forest trails, technical descents‚Äînot smooth gravel
features: Forest singletrack that punishes tired legs

gravel_god_rating.tier_note: Europe's largest gravel event, UCI World Series, 4,000+ riders from 74 countries - prestige override applied

logistics.explanation: Girona is cycling's European hub with excellent infrastructure, but registration sells out in minutes when it opens in July. Emma Porter praises organizers Klassmark: "Any Klassmark event I've been to is always brilliant. It's not only well run, but the atmosphere is excellent." The race provides live tracking and professional coverage, though GPS navigation is mandatory since the course isn't fully marked.

length.explanation: At 360 kilometers, this distance demands multi-day preparation and overnight endurance. Emma Porter's longest training session was "just under 9 hours" preparing for the event. One finisher celebrated: "After 17 hours and 28 minutes, I finally made it. The efforts of the past 5 months have paid off!" The 32-hour cutoff sounds generous until you're grinding technical terrain in darkness with dead legs. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: The course combines everything from smooth hardpack to punishing singletrack. Jonas Orset described "a 7km long singletrack with many loose rocks" where "the final climb before the second refreshment station in Roses was so steep that almost everyone had to push their bikes." Mechanical failures are common - one rider's "mech hanger snapped, flinging itself into the rear wheel and leaving the bike in pieces." More technical than most ‚Äî comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: Emma Porter notes "almost 5,000m of climbing with most of it off-road. It's rough and rugged, steep and stunning." The elevation comes in relentless waves rather than one monster climb, creating tactical racing through Catalonia's varied landscape. The constant undulation from coastal plains to inland hills wears down riders progressively rather than allowing recovery periods between major ascents. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Late April weather in Catalonia proves unpredictable. Jonas Orset experienced the full range: "It's getting hotter, but I enjoy it. After the chilly and dark morning, it's nice to experience weather more familiar to Catalonia. And now it starts raining too." Pete Stetina faced "a race route ripped apart by a week of heavy rain" in 2024, while Timo Rokitta enjoyed "almost perfect" dry conditions in 2023. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting from sea level in Girona means altitude isn't a factor here - your lungs will work fine, your legs are the problem. The coastal plains and rolling hills of Catalonia keep you well below any altitude that matters physiologically. If you're suffering to breathe at these elevations, gravel racing isn't your issue. This is pure power and endurance, not thin air adaptation. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: This race earned the nickname 'Europe's Unbound' for good reason - 1,900 riders from 65+ countries converging on Girona creates an electric atmosphere that transcends typical racing. The course delivers everything from medieval villages to coastal views to technical forest singletrack in one loop. Starting at dawn with a string of red taillights climbing out of the cycling capital of Europe feels like joining something legendary. When WorldTour pros and weekend warriors line up together for 32 hours of potential suffering, you know you've found something special.

prestige.explanation: Dubbed 'Europe's Unbound'‚Äîthe most prestigious gravel race on the continent. Gravel Earth Series flagship event (1,000 points for 360K winner). Attracts WorldTour pros, ex-pros, and elite gravel specialists. Mattia De Marchi, Ted King, Lachlan Morton all race here.

race_quality.explanation: Exceptional organization. Multi-lingual livestream commentary. GPS navigation mandatory. Feed zones well-stocked. Anti-doping controls for podium finishers. The professionalism matches the prestige.

experience.explanation: The complete gravel experience. Start in darkness with 800 riders' taillights winding up the hill. Race through Catalan countryside, coast, and mountains. Finish in Girona's cycling-obsessed atmosphere. The 'party peloton' grupettos at 2 AM. Unforgettable.

community.explanation: Girona is cycling's spiritual home in Europe. 1,900+ riders from 65+ countries. The shared suffering creates bonds‚Äîespecially in the overnight hours. The festival atmosphere continues days around the race. 35%+ of field is female.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 4,000+ riders from 74 countries, the strongest gravel field in Europe. WorldTour names (Lachlan Morton, Ted King, Pete Stetina), gravel specialists (De Marchi, Migon), ultra legends (Sehili, Wilcox). 'The level of riders is insane.' Racing at the front is full pro sport. Elite-level competition, on par with Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Kevin Keresztes puts it: "0-135km (the first feed zone) was quite fast and dusty, eventually settling in with a pack of like 25-30 people."

value.explanation: ~150-200 EUR for 360K is reasonable for an event of this caliber. You get top-tier organization and Europe's premier gravel race. Worth the investment.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs ‚Ç¨80-200. Girona is affordable by European standards‚Äînot Paris or London pricing. Barcelona flights are cheap. Many good hotel options. Budget for a multi-day gravel festival trip. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

biased_opinion.summary: If you're serious about gravel and have any connection to European cycling culture, Traka is a must. It's not just a race‚Äîit's a pilgrimage to the sport's spiritual home. Where else can you suffer on the same roads that Pogaƒçar trains on?
strengths: The location: Girona is cycling heaven. The race is the excuse; the destination is the reward.
The international field: 74 countries. This isn't a regional race.
The legitimacy: UCI points, WorldTour crossover athletes, equal prize purse.
weaknesses: Transatlantic distance: Travel cost and jet lag add complexity for US riders
Crowded early kilometers: 4,000 riders creates bottlenecks
Night racing reality: The 360 almost certainly means riding through darkness
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Traka is Europe's Unbound‚Äîand arguably more technical. If European gravel is on your bucket list, this is the defining event.

final_verdict.one_liner: Europe's Unbound‚Äî360km of technical Mediterranean gravel with Garmin Hill waiting to break you at km 300.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes, if you want Europe's premier gravel experience and can handle 12-18+ hours of racing. Traka delivers WorldTour-level legitimacy, stunning Catalan terrain, and a field from 74 countries. Just be ready for rough sections, Garmin Hill after 300km, and run 44-50mm tires.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want European gravel without the ultra distance: Dirty Reiver (UK, 210km). If you want bucket-list adventure: The Rift (Iceland, volcanic terrain). If you want guaranteed good weather: Unbound (Kansas, June).

logistics.lodging_strategy: Book 6+ months early. Race week is chaos. ‚Ç¨100-200/night. Consider Barcelona + train to Girona.
logistics.food: Girona has excellent restaurants. Book reservations race week‚Äîtown fills with cyclists.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday in Girona. Expo atmosphere, budget 90 minutes.
logistics.parking: Limited. Public transport or hotel shuttles recommended.

history.origin_story: Born in Girona‚Äîwhere WorldTour pros live and train. Exploded from grassroots to Europe's largest gravel event in four years.
notable_moments: Equal prize purse men/women from day one
history.reputation: If Unbound is America's gravel Ironman, Traka is Europe's. The field draws WorldTour crossover athletes and weekend warriors alike.
random_facts: WorldTour pros cross over to race
Girona is cycling's spiritual home‚Äîwhere Pogaƒçar trains

course_description.character: Relentless climbing on Mediterranean gravel. 85% gravel with rough sections better suited to MTB. Flowing early terrain gives way to rougher mid-course chunks.

suffering_zones.label: Early Sectors
suffering_zones.desc: First 135km feels great‚Äîflowing terrain outside Girona. But burning matches here costs you later.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Nice flowing terrain, cool morning air

suffering_zones.label: Mid-Race Rough Sectors
suffering_zones.desc: Some sections questionably rough and better suited to a mountain bike. The terrain starts demanding attention.

suffering_zones.label: Garmin Hill
suffering_zones.desc: The steepest, slowest, most brutal climb of the day. Deep into the ride when legs are cooked. This is where races are decided.

suffering_zones.label: Final Flat Run
suffering_zones.desc: After Garmin Hill and one more climb, a long flat roll home. Fatigue and headwind can make riders crawl.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Long flat drag back to Girona

course_description.signature_challenge: Garmin Hill‚Äîthe steepest, slowest, most brutal climb of the day, hitting when you have 300+ km in your legs.

2024.conditions: (Such times are remarkably fast ‚Äì averaging ~30 km/h over rugged terrain)
key_takeaways: The marquee 360K distance alone drew nearly 800 racers in 2024  (making it arguably the largest gravel ultra in Europe)
From ~100 riders in its 2019 debut, it swelled to 800 participants by 2022
It‚Äôs aimed at newer gravel riders or those looking for a low-key challenge
Introduced in 2024 (though that first edition got rained out), it finally ran in 2025
Weather Challenges: Mud is the biggest adversary when it rains

videos.title: A Story Documenting The TRAKA 360. A One-Day, 360-KM Gravel Race In Girona, Spain.

A story documenting The Traka 360. A one-day, 360-kilometer gravel race, known for its challenging course and vibrant atmosphere, attracting cyclists from around the world.

videos.curation_reason: Professional athlete's first-person race documentation with intimate race preparation and course details from a recent edition.

videos.title: THE TRAKA 2024
videos.description:
Welcome to gravel paradise
Girona breathes cycling in every corner. Grab your gravel bike or MTB and make the dream come true. The best roads, the best landscapes, the best tracks await you; a true postcard photograph where only you are missing. Choose your distance and enjoy your sport. At the gates of Girona you will find everything you have always been looking for. Relax in the old town of the city, experience its culture, mix with its people, enjoy its gastronomy and, above all, cycle like you've never done before.

videos.title: The Traka 360 (2024) - Europe's biggest gravel race
videos.description:
Join me back in Girona racing the Traka 360 for a second time! Will I learn from last year's vomit and dehydration shenanigans?

https://www.instagram.com/maddy_nutty/
https://www.strava.com/pros/6969294

Check out my Patreon if you are keen to support me!
patreon.com/MaddyNutt

Thanks to  @Josh-Reid  for some extra content and Sergi for the thumbnail shot and an extra special thank you to my swanny team.

videos.title: TRAKA 360 COURSE CHECK BEFORE THE RACE!
videos.description:
Part three in our ATLAS carbon launch series, we made it to GIRONA!
It's Wednesday now, and on Saturday we race one of the biggest gravel races of the year; TRAKA 360.  So a little ride to check the course & bikes was in order, ride along!

Also starring a guest appearance of your favourite ex-crewmember...

If you want to support my channel that‚Äôd be amazing, you can ‚Äòjoin‚Äô it here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQuM-Jmy7LbG8jlRgp_Oduw/join

videos.title: Bikes of The Traka: winners, obscure makers, engineers & more at Europe‚Äôs mega gravel event
videos.description:
From global brands to garage tinkerers, there were all sorts of bikes being ridden and raced at distances from 100K to 560K in Girona at The Traka. On the day of the 200K event, I took a stroll around the expo, behind the podium and inside the finishing chute to talk to riders about their bikes and take a close look at the details of the machines that traversed the rowdy Spanish courses.

Two corrections: Mattia De Marchi's bike profile is coming... And I neglected to ID 360K winner Karolina Migo√±'s Rose on screen at 22:41.

Want to see what I'm testing and where? Follow me
on Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/ben-delaney
or on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ben_delaney

--
